Of me must shrivel, from the topmost shoot
Of climbing poesy, and my life, killed through,
Dry down and perish to the foodless root.
author: Francis Thompson, Manus Animam Pinxit

quote: Could we forbear dispute, and practise love,
We should agree as angels do above.
author: Edmund Waller, Divine Poems, Divine Love, Canto III, line 25

quote: In uncertainty I am certain that underneath their topmost layers of frailty men want to be good and want to be loved. Indeed most of their vices are attempted short cuts to love. When a man comes to die, no matter what his talents and influence and genius, if he dies unloved his life must be a failure to him and his dying a cold horror.
author: John Steinbeck in East of Eden

quote: All who have meant good work with their whole hearts, have done good work, although they may die before they have the time to sign it. Every heart that has beat strong and cheerfully has left a hopeful impulse behind it in the world, and bettered the tradition of mankind.
author: Robert Louis Stevenson, Aes Triplex (1878), The Oxford Book of Essays ed. by John Gross (New York: Oxford, 1998) [Title is Latin for "triple brass," used by Horace], p. 316

quote: Time found our tired love sleeping,
And kissed away his breath;
But what should we do weeping,
Though light love sleep to death?
We have drained his lips at leisure,
Till there's not left to drain
A single sob of pleasure,
A single pulse of pain.
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, Poems and Ballads (1866-89), "Rococo", lines 17-24

quote: Want of love is a degree of callousness; for love is the perfection of consciousness. We do not love because we do not comprehend, or rather we do not comprehend because we do not love. For love is the ultimate meaning of everything around us. It is not a mere sentiment; it is truth; it is the joy that is at the root of all creation. It is the white light of pure consciousness that emanates from Brahma. So, to be one with this sarvānubhūh, this all-feeling being who is in the external sky, as well as in our inner soul, we must attain to that summit of consciousness, which is love: Who could have breathed or moved if the sky were not filled with joy, with love?
author: Rabindranath Tagore, Sādhanā : The Realisation of Life (1916)

quote: The truth is, indeed, that love is the threshold of another universe.
author: Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, "The Evolution of Chastity" (1934), as translated by René Hague in Toward the Future (1975)

quote: 'Tis better to have loved and lost,
Than never to have loved at all.
author: Alfred Tennyson, In Memoriam A.H.H. (1849), Part XXVII, Stanza 4

quote: The more God's manifestation in man (life) unites with the manifestations (lives) of other beings, the more man exists. This union with the lives of other beings is accomplished through love.
God is not love, but the more there is of love, the more man manifests God, and the more he truly exists...
author: Leo Tolstoy in his Diary (1 November 1910)

quote: God, from a beautiful necessity, is Love in all he doeth,
Love, a brilliant fire, to gladden or consume:
The wicked work their woe by looking upon love, and hating it:
The righteous find their joys in yearning on its loveliness for ever.
author: Martin Farquhar Tupper, in "Of Immortality" in Proverbial Philosophy (1849)

quote: The world moves for love; it kneels before it in awe.
author: Edward Walker (William Hurt), in The Village

quote: If you say to someone who has ears to hear: "What you are doing to me is not just," you may touch and awaken at its source the spirit of attention and love. But it is not the same with words like, "I have the right..." or "you have no right to..." They evoke a latent war and awaken the spirit of contention.
author: Simone Weil, Human Personality (1943), Written c. 1933; published in Selected Essays 1934-1943, p. 63

quote: All love that has not friendship for its base,
Is like a mansion built upon the sand.
author: Ella Wheeler Wilcox, New Thought Pastels (1913), Love

quote: But is there any comfort to be found?
Man is in love and loves what vanishes,
What more is there to say?
author: William Butler Yeats, Nineteen Hundred And Nineteen I, st. 5-6

quote: To Chloe's breast young Cupid slily stole,
But he crept in at Myra's pocket-hole.
author: William Blake, Couplets and Fragments, IV

quote: I'll bid the hyacinth to blow,
I'll teach my grotto green to be;
And sing my true love, all below
The holly bower and myrtle tree.
author: Thomas Campbell, Caroline, Part I

quote: Banish that fear; my flame can never waste,
For love sincere refines upon the taste.
author: Colley Cibber, The Double Gallant, Act V, scene 1

quote: Say what you will, 'tis better to be left
Than never to have loved.
author: William Congreve, Way of the World, Act II, scene 1

quote: How wise are they that are but fools in love!
author: How a man may choose a Good Wife, Act I. 1. Attributed to Joshua Cooke in Dictioanry of National Biography

quote: Love's great artillery.
author: Richard Crashaw, Prayer, line 18

quote: A ruddy drop of manly blood
The surging sea outweighs;
The world uncertain comes and goes,
The lover rooted stays.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson, Essays, First Series. Epigraph to Friendship

quote: Thus let me hold thee to my heart,
And every care resign:
And we shall never, never part,
My life—my all that's mine!
author: Oliver Goldsmith, The Hermit, Stanza 39

quote: There is a lady sweet and kind,
Was never face so pleased my mind;
I did but see her passing by,
And yet I love her till I die.
author: Ascribed to Robert Herrick in the Scottish Student's Song-Book. Found on back of leaf 53 of Popish Kingdome or reigne of Antichrist, in Latin verse by Thomas Naogeorgus, and Englished by Barnabe Googe. Printed 1570. See Notes and Queries. S. IX. X. 427. Lines from Elizabethan Song-books. Bullen, p. 31. Reprinted from Thomas Ford's Music of Sundry Kinds. (1607)

quote: The more we love a mistress, the nearer we are to hating her.
author: François de La Rochefoucauld, Maxims, 114

quote: A warrior so bold, and a virgin so bright,
Conversed as they sat on the green.
They gazed on each other with tender delight,
Alonzo the Brave was the name of the knight—
The maiden's the Fair Imogene.
author: M. G. Lewis—Alonzo the Brave and the Fair Imogene. First appeared in his novel Ambrosio the Monk. Found in his Tales of Wonder, Volume III, p. 63. Lewis's copy of his poem is in the British Museum

quote: I do not love thee, Dr. Fell.
But why I cannot tell;
But this I know full well,
I do not love thee, Dr. Fell.
author: Paraphrase of Martial by Tom Brown, as given in his Works, ed. by Drake. (1760). Answer to Dean John Fell, of Oxford, IV. 100

quote: Jupiter ex alto perjuria ridet amantum.
author: Ovid, Ars Amatoria, Book I. 633

quote: A lover's soul lives in the body of his mistress.
author: Plutarch

quote: Et l'on revient toujours à ses premiers amours.
author: St. Just

quote: L'amour est un égoïsme à deux.
author: Antoine de Salle

quote: And when my own Mark Antony
Against young Cæsar strove,
And Rome's whole world was set in arms,
The cause was,—all for love.
author: Robert Southey, All for Love, Part II, Stanza 26

quote: For love's humility is Love's true pride.
author: Bayard Taylor, Poet's Journal, Third Evening. The Mother

quote: Nec jurare time; Veneris perjuria venti
Irrita per terras et freta summa ferunt,
Gratia magna Jovi; vetuit pater ipse valere,
Jurasset cupide quicquid ineptus amor.
author: Tibullus, Carmina, I, 4, 21

quote: Our way is where God knows
And Love knows where:
We are in Love’s hand to-day.
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, Love at Sea

quote: The enthusiasm was based on pure love and love of what we were doing.
author: Donald Trump, Crippled America: How to Make America Great Again (2015) Preface, p. xiv

quote: In love, at one of its poles you find the personal, and at the other the impersonal. At one you have the positive assertion — Here I am; at the other the equally strong denial — I am not. Without this ego what is love? And again, with only this ego how can love be possible?

Bondage and liberation are not antagonistic in love. For love is most free and at the same time most bound. If God were absolutely free there would be no creation. The infinite being has assumed unto himself the mystery of finitude. And in him who is love the finite and the infinite are made one.
author: Rabindranath Tagore, Sādhanā : The Realisation of Life (1916)

quote: You say you love your children above all else, and yet you are stealing their future in front of their very eyes...
author: ~Greta Thunberg In an address to world leaders at the United Nations about their failure to address climate change,  (13 December 2018)

quote: You're dressed in that dress, I like. Love is swinging in the air, tonight.
author: Justin Timberlake, "Suit & Tie" (2013), The 20/20 Experience (2013)

quote: If in your relationships you experience both "love" and the opposite of love - attack, emotional violence, and so on - then it is likely that you are confusing ego attachment and addictive clinging with love. You cannot love your partner one moment and attack him or her the next. True love has no opposite. If your "love" has an opposite, then it is not love but a strong ego-need for a more complete and deeper sense of self, a need that the other person temporarily meets. It is the ego's substitute for salvation, and for a short time it almost does feel like salvation.

But there comes a point when your partner behaves in ways that fail to meet your needs, or rather those of your ego. The feelings of fear, pain, and lack that are an intrinsic part of egoic consciousness but had been covered up by the "love relationship" now resurface. Just as with every other addiction, you are on a high when the drug is available, but invariably there comes a time when the drug no longer works for you.
author: Eckhart Tolle in A New Earth: Awakening to Your Life's Purpose, Chapter 8, Enlightened Relationships, (2005)

quote: I have now understood that though it seems to men that they live by care for themselves, in truth it is love alone by which they live. He who has love, is in God, and God is in him, for God is love.
author: Leo Tolstoy in "What Men Live By" (1881)

quote: There are many kinds of love, as many kinds of light,
And every kind of love makes a glory in the night.
There is love that stirs the heart, and love that gives it rest,
But the love that leads life upward is the noblest and the best.
author: Henry van Dyke, Love and Light

quote: Improbe Amor, quid non mortalia pectora cogis!
All-powerful Love! what changes canst thou cause
In human hearts, subjected to thy laws!
Virgil, Aeneid (29–19 BC), Book IV, line 412 (as translated by John Dryden); referring to the unwise actions undertaken by Dido, actuated by amorous passion.
author: Variant translation: Oh wretched love! to what do you not impel the human breast?

quote: I know you love your wife Joe. Do you know how love is defined? Josef Pieper described it in this way: Love is a fundamental YES to the existence of the beloved. Well, you know what contraception is? First of all it is a NO to your wife's fertility which is not something she has, but something she is [therefore contraception is a fundamental NO to your wife because of the intimate union between her body and her soul]. Secondly, contraception is a fundamental NO to the potential existence of the child. Therefore, this fundamental NO, inserted in the most intimate expression of conjugal love, contradicts the very nature of love [the YES to the existence of the other] and as such will inexorably erode the love between any husband and wife who practice contraception.
author: Fr. Emmanuel Vita; in Fr. Augustine Mary “Contraception, What's Allowed?“, EWTN, (1996)

quote: I would dare to say that love is God living in our midst.
author: Reginald somerset Ward. As quoted in Reginald Somerset Ward 1881-1882, His life and Letters, ed.E.R.Morgan. Mowbray, 1962. P.68

quote: There is no formula for generating the authentic warmth of love. It cannot be copied. You cannot talk yourself into it or rouse it by straining at the emotions or by dedicating yourself solemnly to the service of mankind. Everyone has love, but it can only come out when he is convinced of the impossibility and the frustration of trying to love himself. This conviction will not come through condemnations, through hating oneself, through calling self love bad names in the universe. It comes only in the awareness that one has no self to love.
author: Alan Watts, The Wisdom of Insecurity (1951)

quote: Be not dishearten'd, affection shall solve the problems of freedom yet,
Those who love each other shall become invincible...
author: Walt Whitman in Leaves of Grass, DRUM-TAPS, Over the Carnage Rose Prophetic a Voice (1860; 1867)

quote: Divine the Powers that on this trio wait.
Supreme their conquest, over Time and Fate.
Love, Work, and Faith — these three alone are great.
author: Ella Wheeler Wilcox, New Thought Pastels (1913), Three Things

quote: Speech after long silence; it is right,
All other lovers being estranged or dead,
Unfriendly lamplight hid under its shade,
The curtains drawn upon unfriendly night,
That we descant and yet again descant
Upon the supreme theme of Art and Song:
Bodily decrepitude is wisdom; young
We loved each other and were ignorant.
author: William Butler Yeats, After Long Silence in The Winding Stair and Other Poems (1933)

quote: Le premier soupir de l'amour
Est le dernier de la sagesse.
author: Antoine Bret, Ecole amoureuse, scene 7

quote: Never the time and the place
And the loved one all together.
author: Robert Browning, Never the Time and the Place

quote: Pains of love be sweeter far
Than all other pleasures are.
author: John Dryden, Tyrannic Love, Act IV, scene 1

quote: He is not a lover who does not love for ever.
author: Euripides, Troades, 1,051

quote: Love is the tyrant of the heart; it darkens
Reason, confounds discretion; deaf to Counsel
It runs a headlong course to desperate madness.
author: John Ford, The Lover's Melancholy (licensed 24 November 1628; printed 1629), Act III, scene 3, line 105

quote: It is difficult to know at what moment love begins; it is less difficult to know that it has begun.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Kavanagh: A Tale (1849), Chapter XXI

quote: Nothing is more hateful than love.
author: John Lyly, Euphues

quote: Non amo te, Sabidi, nec possum dicere quare;
Hoc tantum posse dicere: non amo te.
author: Martial, Epigrams (c. 80-104 AD), I. 33. 1. (Name sometimes given "Savidi.")

quote: A boat at midnight sent alone
To drift upon the moonless sea,
A lute, whose leading chord is gone,
A wounded bird, that hath but one
Imperfect wing to soar upon,
Are like what I am, without thee.
author: Thomas Moore, Loves of the Angels, Second Angel's Story

quote: I've wandered east, I've wandered west,
I've bourne a weary lot;
But in my wanderings far or near
Ye never were forgot.
The fount that first burst frae this heart
Still travels on its way
And channels deeper as it rins
The luve o' life's young day.
author: William Motherwell, Jeanie Morrison

quote: The hours I spent with thee, dear heart,
Are as a string of pearls to me;
I count them over, every one apart,
My rosary, my rosary.
author: Robert Cameron Rogers, My Rosary

quote: Si vis amari, ama.
author: Seneca the Younger, Epistolæ Ad Lucilium, IX. Ausonius—Epigrams. XCI. 6. Martial, Epigrams, VI. 11. Ovid, Ars Amatoria, II. 107. Attributed to Plato by Burton

quote: My true-love hath my heart, and I have his,
By just exchange, one for the other given;
I hold his dear, and mine he cannot miss,
There never was a better bargain driven.
author: Sir Philip Sidney, My True Love Hath my Heart

quote: Priests, altars, victims, swam before my sight.
author: Edmund Smith, Phædra and Hippolytus, Act I, scene 1

quote: Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it.
author: Song of Solomon, VIII. 7

quote: Love better is than Fame.
author: Bayard Taylor, Christmas Sonnets, Lyrics. To J. L. G

quote: Let this be my last word, that I trust in thy love.
author: Rabindranath Tagore, Stray Birds (1916), 326

quote: As the gambler said of his dice, to love and win is the best thing, to love and lose is the next best.
author: William Makepeace Thackeray, The History of Pendennis (1848-1850), Ch. 40

quote: Sweet is true love though given in vain, in vain;
And sweet is death who puts an end to pain:
I know not which is sweeter, no, not I. Love, art thou sweet? then bitter death must be:
Love, thou art bitter; sweet is death to me.
O Love, if death be sweeter, let me die.
I fain would follow love, if that could be;
I needs must follow death, who calls for me;
Call and I follow, I follow! let me die.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Idylls of the King (1856–1885), chapter Lancelot and Elaine, line 1000

quote: It is best to love wisely, no doubt; but to love foolishly is better than not to be able to love at all. Some of us can't: and are proud of our impotence, too.
author: William Makepeace Thackeray, The History of Pendennis (1848-1850), Ch. 6

quote: I feel it in my fingers
I feel it in my toes
Love is all around me
And so the feeling grows
It is written on the wind
Thats everywhere I go
So if you really love me
Come on and let it show
author: The Troggs, Love Is All Around (1967)

quote: Life is ever lord of Death
And Love can never lose its own.
author: John Greenleaf Whittier, Snow Bound, reported in Bartlett's Familiar Quotations, 10th ed. (1919)

quote: Between the finite and the infinite
The missing link of Love has left a void.
Supply the link, and earth with Heaven will join
In one continued chain of endless life.
author: Ella Wheeler Wilcox, New Thought Pastels (1913), The Way (1913)

quote: Those who are faithful know only the trivial side of love; it is the faithless who know love's tragedies.
author: Oscar Wilde, The Picture of Dorian Gray, ch. 1

quote: There is a land of the living and a land of the dead and the bridge is love, the only survival, the only meaning.
author: Thornton Wilder in The Bridge of San Luis Rey (1927), final sentence

quote: If we wait for the world’s permission to shine, we will never receive it. The ego doesn’t give that permission. Only God does, and He has already done so. He has sent you here as His personal representative and is asking you to channel His love into the world. Are you waiting for a more important job? There isn’t one.
author: Marianne Williamson in A Return to Love: Reflections on the Principles of "A Course in Miracles" (1992) Ch. 7

quote: A long time ago, Anne used to talk about energy—how that was all that love was—ions connecting across synapses of time and air. Don't rationalize, she'd say. None of it will ever make sense. I leaned back against the wall and closed my eyes, not wanting to cry. Anne was right. None of it made any sense.
Jacqueline Woodson, If You Come Softly (1998) p. 58
author: Fiction; inner thoughts of Elisha

quote: Love is in the air
In the whisper of the trees
Love is in the air
In the thunder of the sea
And I don't know if I'm just dreaming
Don't know if I feel sane
But it's something that I must believe in
And it's there when you call out my name.
author: John Paul Young, in "Love Is in the Air" (1977)

quote: Somewhere there waiteth in this world of ours
For one lone soul another lonely soul,
Each choosing each through all the weary hours,
And meeting strangely at one sudden goal,
Then blend they, like green leaves with golden flowers,
Into one beautiful and perfect whole;
And life's long night is ended, and the way
Lies open onward to eternal day.
author: Edwin Arnold, Somewhere There Waiteth

quote: When things were as fine as could possibly be
I thought 'twas the spring; but alas it was she.
author: John Byrom, A Pastoral

quote: Vivunt in venerem frondes omnisque vicissim
Felix arbor amat; mutant ad mutua palmæ
Fœdera.
author: Claudianus, De Nuptiis Honorii et Mariæ, LXV

quote: Alas! they had been friends in youth;
But whispering tongues can poison truth,
And constancy lives in realms above;
And life is thorny, and youth is vain;
And to be wroth with one we love
Doth work like madness in the brain.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Christabel (c. 1797-1801, published 1816), Part II

quote: I know not when the day shall be,
I know not when our eyes may meet;
What welcome you may give to me,
Or will your words be sad or sweet,
It may not be 'till years have passed,
'Till eyes are dim and tresses gray;
The world is wide, but, love, at last,
Our hands, our hearts, must meet some day.
author: Hugh Conway, Some Day

quote: He who, being bold
For life to come, is false to the past sweet
Of mortal life, hath killed the world above.
For why to live again if not to meet?
And why to meet if not to meet in love?
And why in love if not in that dear love of old?
author: Sydney Dobell, Sonnet, To a Friend in Bereavement

quote: Give, you gods,
Give to your boy, your Cæsar,
The rattle of a globe to play withal,
This gewgaw world, and put him cheaply off;
I'll not be pleased with less than Cleopatra.
author: John Dryden, All for Love, Act II, scene 1

quote: The solid, solid universe
Is pervious to Love;
With bandaged eyes he never errs,
Around, below, above.
His blinding light
He flingeth white
On God's and Satan's brood,
And reconciles
By mystic wiles
The evil and the good.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson, Cupido

quote: When love is at its best, one loves
So much that he cannot forget.
author: Helen Hunt Jackson, Two Truths

quote: Le commencement et le déclin de l'amour se font sentir par l'embarras où l'on est de se trouver seuls.
author: Jean de La Bruyère, Les Caractères, IV

quote: But thou, through good and evil, praise and blame,
Wilt not thou love me for myself alone?
Yes, thou wilt love me with exceeding love,
And I will tenfold all that love repay;
Still smiling, though the tender may reprove,
Still faithful, though the trusted may betray.
author: Thomas Babington Macaulay, 1st Baron Macaulay, Lines Written July 30, 1847

quote: Love is a flame to burn out human wills,
Love is a flame to set the will on fire,
Love is a flame to cheat men into mire.
author: John Masefield, Widow in the Bye Street, Part II

quote: It is good to be merry and wise,
It is good to be honest and true,
It is best to be off with the old love,
Before you are on with the new.
author: Published in "Songs of England and Scotland." London, 1835, Volume II, p. 73

quote: But there's nothing half so sweet in life
As love's young dream.
author: Thomas Moore, Love's Young Dream, Stanza 1

quote: The moods of love are like the wind,
And none knows whence or why they rise.
author: Coventry Patmore, The Angel in the House, Sarum Plain

quote: Ah! what avails it me the flocks to keep,
Who lost my heart while I preserv'd my sheep.
author: Alexander Pope, Autumn, line 79

quote: Ein liebendes Mädchen wird unbewust kühner.
author: Jean Paul Richter, Titan, Zykel 71

quote: Mortals, while through the world you go,
Hope may succor and faith befriend,
Yet happy your hearts if you can but know,
Love awaits at the journey's end!
author: Clinton Scollard, The Journey's End—Envoy

quote: Love is strong as death; jealousy is cruel as the grave.
author: Song of Solomon, VIII. 6

quote: Love's history, as Life's, is ended not
By marriage.
author: Bayard Taylor, Lars, Book III

quote: At first, she loved nought else but flowers,
And then—she only loved the rose;
And then—herself alone; and then—
She knew not what, but now—she knows.
author: Ridgely Torrence, House of a Hundred Lights

quote: "I'm sorry that I spell'd the word;
I hate to go above you,
Because"—the brown eyes lower fell,—
"Because, you see, I love you!"
author: John Greenleaf Whittier, In School-Days, Stanza 4

quote: Farewell, Love, and all thy laws for ever.
Sir Thomas Wyatt, Songs and Sonnets, A Renouncing of Love.
author: With every act of love we move a little closer to immortality, whereas every act of hate brings us nearer to death. Recueil de Caprices

quote: Les plaisirs et les soins de l'ambition la plus heureuse, même du pouvoir sans bornes, ne sont rien auprès du bonheur intime que donnent les relations de tendresse et d'amour. Je suis homme avant d'être prince, et, quand j'ai le bonheur d'aimer, ma maîtresse s'adresse à l'homme et non au prince.

The pleasures and the cares of the luckiest ambition, even of limitless power, are nothing next to the intimate happiness that tenderness and love give. I am a man before being a prince, and when I have the good fortune to be in love my mistress addresses a man and not a prince.
author: Stendhal, La Chartreuse de Parme (The Charterhouse of Parma) (1839), Ch. 7

quote: The loves and hours of the life of a man,
They are swift and sad, being born of the sea.
Hours that rejoice and regret for a span,
Born with a man's breath, mortal as he;
Loves that are lost ere they come to birth,
Weeds of the wave, without fruit upon earth.
I lose what I long for, save what I can,
My love, my love, and no love for me!
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, The Triumph of Time

quote: How come we don't always know when love begins, but we always know when it ends?
author: Harris K. Telemacher (Steve Martin) in L. A. Story

quote: Love lieth deep; Love dwells not in lip-depths.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Lover's Tale (1879), line 466

quote: Yet is there one true line, the pearl of pearls:
Man dreams of Fame while woman wakes to love.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Idylls of the King (1859-1865), Merlin and Vivien

quote: I will love thee to the death,
And out beyond into the dream to come.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Idylls of the King (1859-1865), The Last Tournament

quote: I just sware
That I'll always be there
I'd give anything and everything
And I will always care
Through weekness and strength
Happiness and sorrow
For better or for worse
I will love you
With every beat of my heart.
author: Shania Twain, From This Moment On, (1998) from the 1997 album Come On Over

quote: Qui que tu sois, voici ton maître;
Il l'est—le fut—ou le doit être.
author: Voltaire, Works, II, p. 765 (Ed. 1837). Used as an inscription for a statue of Cupid

quote: Love is where you find it. I think it is foolish to go looking for it, and I think it can often be poisonous.
author: Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. from the prologue of Slapstick (1976)

quote: I wish that people who are conventionally supposed to love each other would say to each other, when they fight, "Please — a little less love, and a little more common decency."
author: Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. from the prologue of Slapstick (1976)

quote: Could we forbear dispute, and practise love,
We should agree as angels do above.
author: Edmund Waller, in "Of Divine Love" (c. 1686)

quote: Taylor: Imagine me needing someone. Back on Earth I never did. Oh, there were women. Lots of women. Lots of love-making but no love. You see, that was the kind of world we'd made. So I left, because there was no one to hold me there.
author: Planet of the Apes (1968 film), screenplay by Michael Wilson and Rod Serling

quote: Just let your love flow like a mountain stream
And let your love grow.
Larry E. Williams, in Let Your Love Flow (1976)
author: There is no more powerful motivation than to feel we’re being used in the creation of a world where love has healed all wounds. We are no longer ambitious for ourselves, but are rather inspired by the vision of a healed world.

quote: Love in a shower safe shelter took,
In a rosy bower beside a brook,
And winked and nodded with conscious pride
To his votaries drenched on the other side.
Come hither, sweet maids, there's a bridge below,
The toll-keeper, Hymen, will let you through.
Come over the stream to me.
author: Bloomfield, Glee, Stanza 1

quote: Behold me! I am worthy
Of thy loving, for I love thee!
author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Lady Geraldine's Courtship, Stanza 79

quote: Of all the girls that are so smart
There's none like pretty Sally;
She is the darling of my heart,
And lives in our alley.
author: Henry Carey, Sally in our Alley

quote: Vivamus, mea Lesbia atque amemus.
author: Catullus, Carmina, V. 1

quote: Difficile est longum subito deponere amorem.
author: Catullus, Carmina, LXXVI. 13

quote: Her very frowns are fairer far
Than smiles of other maidens are.
author: Hartley Coleridge, Song, She is not Fair

quote: Love, Love, my Love.
The best things are the truest!
When the earth lies shadowy dark below
Oh, then the heavens are bluest!
author: R. W. Gilder, The New Day, Part IV. Song I

quote: Wenn ich dich lieb habe, was geht's dich an?
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Wilhelm Meister, IV. 9

quote: If you become a Nun, dear,
The bishop Love will be;
The Cupids every one, dear!
Will chant—'We trust in thee!'
author: Leigh Hunt, The Nun

quote: Sing, for faith and hope are high—
None so true as you and I—
Sing the Lovers' Litany:
"Love like ours can never die!"
author: Rudyard Kipling, Lovers Litany

quote: Amour! Amour! quand tu nous tiens
On peut bien dire, Adieu, prudence.
author: Jean de La Fontaine, Fables, IV. 1

quote: Does not all the blood within me
Leap to meet thee, leap to meet thee,
As the springs to meet the sunshine.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, The Song of Hiawatha (1855), Wedding Feast, line 153

quote: Tell me not, sweet, I am unkind,
That from the nunnery
Of thy chaste breast and quiet mind
To war and arms I fly.
Yet this inconstancy is such
As you too shall adore:—
I could not love thee, dear, so much,
Loved I not honour more.
author: Richard Lovelace, To Lucasta, on going to the Wars. Given erroneously to Montrose by Scott

quote: It is better to poyson hir with the sweet bait of love.
author: John Lyly, Euphues

quote: Je ne vous aime pas, Hylas;
Je n'en saurois dire la cause;
Je sais seulement une chose.
C'est que je ne vous aime pas.
author: Paraphrase of Martial by Robert Rabutin (De Bussy)—Epigram 32, Book I

quote: 'Tis well to be merry and wise,
'Tis well to be honest and true;
'Tis well to be off with the old love,
Before you are on with the new.
author: As used by Charles Maturin, for the motto to "Bertram," produced at Drury Lane, 1816

quote: Quicquid Amor jussit non est contemnere tutum.
Regnat, et in dominos jus habet ille deos.
author: Ovid, Heroides, IV. 11

quote: Where shall the lover rest,
Whom the fates sever
From his true maiden's breast,
Parted for ever?
Where, through groves deep and high,
Sounds the far billow,
Where early violets die,
Under the willow.
author: Walter Scott, Marmion (1808), Canto III, Stanza 10

quote: Cupid "the little greatest god."
author: Robert Southey, Commonplace Book. 4th Series, p. 462

quote: Die Liebe wintert nicht;
Nein, nein! Ist und bleibt Frühlings-Schein.
author: Ludwig Tieck, Herbstlied

quote: O dearer far than light and life are dear.
author: William Wordsworth, Poems Founded on the Affections, No. XIX. To. ——, VII. 114

quote: God recommends his own love to us in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
author: Paul of Tarsus, Romans 5:8, NWT
Driven by the forces of love, the fragments of the world seek each other so that the world may come into being.

quote: I call love the recognizing of yourself in the other, and yourself your essential self.
author: Eckhart Tolle quoted in The Wisdom of Sundays: Life-Changing Insights from Super Soul Conversations, by Oprah Winfrey,  (17 October 2017)

quote: Seize the moments of happiness, love and be loved! That is the only reality in the world, all else is folly.
author: Leo Tolstoy in War and Peace (1865-1869)

quote: Belief in the existence of other human beings as such is love.
author: Simone Weil, Gravity and Grace (1972), p. 56

quote: The mystery of love is greater than the mystery of death.
author: Oscar Wilde, Salomé (1893)

quote: Love is the true antithesis of fear. It expands where fear constricts. It embraces where fear repels.
author: Marion Woodman and Elinor Dickson, Dancing in the Flames: The Dark Goddess in the Transformation of Consciousness, p. 45 (1997)

quote: Love is like fire.
Wounds of fire are hard to bear; harder still are those of love.
author: w:Hjalmar Hjorth BoyesenHjalmar Hjorth Boyesen, Gunnar, Chapter IV

quote: For none can express thee, though all should approve thee.
I love thee so, Dear, that I only can love thee.
author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Insufficiency

quote: God be thanked, the meanest of his creatures
Boasts two soul-sides, one to face the world with,
One to show a woman when he loves her.
author: Robert Browning, One Word More, Stanza XVII

quote: My love lies bleeding.
author: Thomas Campbell, O'Connor's Child, Stanza 5

quote: It's love, it's love that makes the world go round.
author: Popular French song in Chansons Nationales et Populaires de France, Volume II, p. 180 (c. 1821)

quote: He that can't live upon love deserves to die in a ditch.
author: William Congreve

quote: Wedded love is founded on esteem.
author: Elijah Fenton, Mariamne

quote: Not from the whole wide world I chose thee,
Sweetheart, light of the land and the sea!
The wide, wide world could not inclose thee,
For thou art the whole wide world to me.
author: R. W. Gilder, Song

quote: You say to me-wards your affection's strong;
Pray love me little, so you love me long.
author: Robert Herrick, Love me Little, Love me Long

quote: Love's like the flies, and, drawing-room or garret, goes all over a house.
author: Douglas Jerrold, Jerrold's Wit, Love

quote: The lover in the husband may be lost.
author: George Lyttelton, 1st Baron Lyttelton, Advice to a Lady, Stanza 13

quote: None without hope e'er lov'd the brightest fair:
But Love can hope where Reason would despair.
author: George Lyttelton, 1st Baron Lyttelton, Epigram

quote: I love thee not, Nell
But why I can't tell.
author: Paraphrase of Martial in Thomas Forde's Virtus Rediviva

quote: Ye gods, annihilate but space and time,
And make two lovers happy.
author: Alexander Pope, Martinus Scriblerus on the Art of Sinking in Poetry, Chapter XI

quote: Divine is Love and scorneth worldly pelf,
And can be bought with nothing but with self.
author: Sir Walter Raleigh, Love the Only Price of Love

quote: As one who cons at evening o'er an album all alone,
And muses on the faces of the friends that he has known,
So I turn the leaves of Fancy, till in shadowy design
I find the smiling features of an old sweetheart of mine.
author: James Whitcomb Riley, An Old Sweetheart of Mine

quote: They love indeed who quake to say they love.
author: Sir Philip Sidney, Astrophel and Stella, LIV

quote: Love in its essence is spiritual fire.
author: Emanuel Swedenborg, True Christian Religion, Par. 31

quote: It is best to love wisely, no doubt; but to love foolishly is better than not to be able to love at all.
author: William Makepeace Thackeray, Pendennis, Chapter VI

quote: For all true love is grounded on esteem.
author: Villiers (Duke of Buckingham)

quote: To love is to believe, to hope, to know;
'Tis an essay, a taste of Heaven below!
author: Edmund Waller, Divine Poems, Divine Love, Canto III, line 17

quote: While all the future, for thy purer soul,
With "sober certainties" of love is blest.
author: William Wordsworth, Poems Founded on the Affections, VII. 115. (Knight's ed.)

quote: If love were what the rose is,
And I were like the leaf,
Our lives would grow together
In sad or singing weather,
Blown fields or flowerful closes,
Green pasture or gray grief;
If love were what the rose is,
And I were like the leaf.
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, Poems and Ballads (1866-89), "A Match"

quote: Let your love flow out on all living things. These words at some level have the quality of a strapping homily. Nonetheless, they are remarkably beautiful, strung together in their honest lump-like English syllables... Let your love flow out on all living things.

But there are a couple of problems with this precept of mine. The first is, of course, that it is not mine. It springs from the universe and is the property of God, and the words have been intercepted — on the wing, so to speak — by such mediators as Lao-tzu, Jesus, Gautama Buddha and thousands upon thousands of lesser prophets, including your narrator, who heard the terrible truth of their drumming somewhere between Baltimore and Wilmington and set them down with the fury of a madman sculpting in stone.
William Styron, Sophie's Choice (1979), Ch. 16
author: The italicized words being quotes of the song "Let Your Love Flow " by Larry E. Williams, as sung by The Bellamy Brothers

quote: The pulse of war and passion of wonder,
The heavens that murmur, the sounds that shine,
The stars that sing and the loves that thunder,
The music burning at heart like wine,
An armed archangel whose hands raise up
All senses mixed in the spirit's cup
Till flesh and spirit are molten in sunder —
These things are over, and no more mine.These were a part of the playing I heard
Once, ere my love and my heart were at strife;
Love that sings and hath wings as a bird,
Balm of the wound and heft of the knife.
Fairer than earth is the sea, and sleep
Than overwatching of eyes that weep,
Now time has done with his one sweet word,
The wine and leaven of lovely life.
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, The Triumph of Time

quote: Of course man is useful to man, because his body is a marvellous machine and his mind an organ of wonderful efficiency. But he is a spirit as well, and this spirit is truly known only by love. When we define a man by the market value of the service we can expect of him, we know him imperfectly. With this limited knowledge of him it becomes easy for us to be unjust to him and to entertain feelings of triumphant self-congratulation when, on account of some cruel advantage on our side, we can get out of him much more than we have paid for. But when we know him as a spirit we know him as our own. We at once feel that cruelty to him is cruelty to ourselves, to make him small is stealing from our own humanity...
author: Rabindranath Tagore, Sādhanā : The Realisation of Life (1916)

quote: Compulsion is not indeed the final appeal to man, but joy is. And joy is everywhere; it is in the earth's green covering of grass; in the blue serenity of the sky; in the reckless exuberance of spring; in the severe abstinence of grey winter; in the living flesh that animates our bodily frame; in the perfect poise of the human figure, noble and upright; in living; in the exercise of all our powers; in the acquisition of knowledge; in fighting evils; in dying for gains we never can share. Joy is there everywhere; it is superfluous, unnecessary; nay, it very often contradicts the most peremptory behests of necessity. It exists to show that the bonds of law can only be explained by love; they are like body and soul. Joy is the realisation of the truth of oneness, the oneness of our soul with the world and of the world-soul with the supreme lover.
author: Rabindranath Tagore, Sādhanā : The Realisation of Life (1916)

quote: Who are wise in love
Love most, say least
author: Alfred Tennyson, Idylls of the King (1859-1865), Merlin and Vivien

quote: The throb of life is love. Without it, humans are bodies of bones clad with skin.
author: Tiruvalluvar, Tirukkural: 80

quote: For Truth makes holy Love's illusive dreams,
And their best promise constantly redeems.
author: Henry Theodore Tuckerman, "Sonnet XXII", in Poems (Boston: Ticknor, Reed, and Fields, 1851), p. 168

quote: In your eyes
(I can still see the look of the one)
I can still see the look
Of the one who really loves me
(II can still feel the way that you want)
The one who wouldn't put anything
Else in the world above me
(I can still see your love for me)
I can still see your love for me in your eyes
(I still see the love)
author: Shania Twain, Forever and for Always, (2003) from the 2003 album Up!

quote: Make love when you can. It's good for you.
author: Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. in Mother Night (1961)

quote: Love does not care for time or order.
author: Mallanaga Vātsyāyana, Kama Sutra, Part II, Chapter III

quote: One of the most exquisite pleasures of human love — to serve the loved one without his knowing it — is only possible, as regards the love of God, through atheism.
author: Simone Weil, First and Last Notebooks (1970), Last Notebook (1942) p. 84

quote: He who does not realize to what extent shifting fortune and necessity hold in subjection every human spirit, cannot regard as fellow-creatures nor love as he loves himself those whom chance separated from him by an abyss. The variety of constraints pressing upon man give rise to the illusion of several distinct species that cannot communicate. Only he who has measured the dominion of force, and knows how not to respect it, is capable of love and justice.
author: Simone Weil, The Iliad or The Poem of Force (1940-1941), p. 192

quote: * Blow again trumpeter! and for thy theme,
Take now the enclosing theme of all, the solvent and the setting,
Love, that is pulse of all, the sustenance and the pang,
The heart of man and woman all for love,
No other theme but love — knitting, enclosing, all-diffusing love.
author: Walt Whitman in Leaves of Grass, The Mystic Trumpeter

quote: Even in the most perfect love one person loves less profoundly than the other.
author: Thornton Wilder in The Bridge of San Luis Rey (1927)

quote: Falling in love is the one illogical adventure, the one thing of which we are tempted to think as supernatural, in our trite and reasonable world. The effect is out of all proportion with the cause. Two persons, neither of them, it may be, very amiable or very beautiful, meet, speak a little, and look a little into each other's eyes. That has been done a dozen or so of times in the experience of either with no great result. But on this occasion all is different. They fall at once into that state in which another person becomes to us the very gist and centrepoint of God's creation, and demolishes our laborious theories with a smile; in which our ideas are so bound up with the one master-thought that even the trivial cares of our own person become so many acts of devotion, and the love of life itself is translated into a wish to remain in the same world with so precious and desirable a fellow-creature.
author: Robert Louis Stevenson, Virginibus Puerisque, Ch. 3

quote: In every bit of honest writing in the world … there is a base theme. Try to understand men, if you understand each other you will be kind to each other. Knowing a man well never leads to hate and nearly always leads to love. There are shorter means, many of them. there is writing promoting social change, writing punishing injustice, writing in celebration of heroism, but always that base theme. Try to understand each other.
author: John Steinbeck in East of Eden, Journal entry (1938), quoted in the Introduction to a 1994 edition of Of Mice and Men by Susan Shillinglaw, p. vii

quote: Never give all the heart, for love
Will hardly seem worth thinking of
To passionate women if it seem
Certain, and they never dream
That it fades out from kiss to kiss;
For everything that's lovely is
but a brief, dreamy, kind of delight.
O never give the heart outright,
For they, for all smooth lips can say,
Have given their hearts up to the play.
And who could play it well enough
If deaf and dumb and blind with love?
He that made this knows all the cost,
For he gave all his heart and lost.
author: William Butler Yeats, Never Give All The Heart in In The Seven Woods (1904)

quote: I love her doubling and anguish;
I love the love she withholds,
I love my love that loveth her,
And anew her being moulds.
author: R. W. Gilder, The New Day, Part III. Song XV

quote: Es ist eine der grössten Himmelsgaben,
So ein lieb' Ding im Arm zu haben.
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Faust

quote: And once again we plighted our troth,
And titter'd, caress'd, kiss'd so dearly.
author: Heinrich Heine, Youthful Sorrows. No. 57, Stanza 2

quote: If Love were jester at the court of Death,
And Death the king of all, still would I pray,
"For me the motley and the bauble, yea,
Though all be vanity, as the Preacher saith,
The mirth of love be mine for one brief breath!"
author: Frederic L. Knowles, If Love were Jester at the Court of Death

quote: Ce qui fait que amants et les maitresses ne s'ennuient point d'être ensemble; c'est qu'ils parlent toujours d'eux mêmes.
author: François de La Rochefoucauld, Maximes (1665–1678), 312

quote: Not as all other women are
Is she that to my soul is dear;
Her glorious fancies come from far,
Beneath the silver evening star,
And yet her heart is ever near.
author: James Russell Lowell, My Love, Stanza 1

quote: Come live with me, and be my love,
And we will all the pleasures prove,
That valleys, groves, or hills, or fields,
Or woods and steepy mountains, yield.
author: Christopher Marlowe, The Passionate Shepherd to his Love, Stanza 1

quote: Celuy ayme peu qui ayme à la mesure.
author: Michel de Montaigne, Essays, Book I, Chapter XXVIII

quote: Res est soliciti plena timoris amor.
author: Ovid, Heroides, I. 12

quote: Magis gauderes quod habueras, quam moereres quod amiseras.
author: Seneca the Younger, Epistles, 99

quote: Odit verus amor nec patitur moras.
author: Seneca the Younger, Hercules Furens, 588

quote: I that have love and no more
Give you but love of you, sweet;
He that hath more, let him give;
He that hath wings, let him soar;
Mine is the heart at your feet
Here, that must love you to live.
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, The Oblation

quote: Tum, ut adsolet in amore et ira, jurgia, preces, exprobrutio, satisfactio.
author: Tacitus, Annales (AD 117), XIII. 44

quote: I love thee, I love but thee,
With a love that shall not die
Till the sun grows cold,
And the stars are old,
And the leaves of the Judgment Book unfold!
author: Bayard Taylor, Bedouin Song
Love is the center of holiness. Loving God above all and loving others like ourselves summarize the Ten commandments.

quote: We never can have a true view of man unless we have a love for him. Civilisation must be judged and prized, not by the amount of power it has developed, but by how much it has evolved and given expression to, by its laws and institutions, the love of humanity. The first question and the last which it has to answer is, Whether and how far it recognises man more as a spirit than a machine? Whenever some ancient civilisation fell into decay and died, it was owing to causes which produced callousness of heart and led to the cheapening of man's worth; when either the state or some powerful group of men began to look upon the people as a mere instrument of their power; when, by compelling weaker races to slavery and trying to keep them down by every means, man struck at the foundation of his greatness, his own love of freedom and fair-play. Civilisation can never sustain itself upon cannibalism of any form. For that by which alone man is true can only be nourished by love and justice.
author: Rabindranath Tagore, Sādhanā : The Realisation of Life (1916)

quote: God gives us love. Something to love
He lends us; but when love is grown
To ripeness, that on which it throve
Falls off, and love is left alone.
author: Alfred Tennyson, To J. S., stanza 4, from Poems (1832)

quote: To Love  is to recognize yourself in another.
author: Eckhart Tolle quoted in The Wisdom of Sundays: Life-Changing Insights from Super Soul Conversations, by Oprah Winfrey,  (17 October 2017)

quote: The reason why the romantic love relationship is such an intense and universally sought-after experience is that it seems to offer liberation from a deep-seated state of fear, need, lack, and incompleteness that is part of the human condition in its unredeemed and unenlightened state.
author: Eckhart Tolle, The Power of Now (1997)

quote: As soon as men live entirely in accord with the law of love natural to their hearts and now revealed to them, which excludes all resistance by violence, and therefore hold aloof from all participation in violence — as soon as this happens, not only will hundreds be unable to enslave millions, but not even millions will be able to enslave a single individual.
author: Leo Tolstoy in "A Letter to a Hindu" (1908)

quote: You say love is a temple, love a higher law
Love is a temple, love the higher law
You ask me to enter but then you make me crawl
And I can't be holdin' on to what you got
When all you got is hurt
author: U2, One (6 March 1992) from the 1990 album Achtung Baby

quote: What are we to do about those countless men and women and children, in distress and perhaps in despair, who are our brothers and sisters? There are practical things—small things perhaps, but practical, and important—that we can do, and must try to do; but first let us be clear about one thing, the thing on which all the practical help must be built if it is to be of real value to the world in the long run: the fact that love is something in the will, the will to share other people's burdens, and that this will can come only from a humble heart.
author: Gerald Vann, The Two Trees (1948). London: Collins, p. 35

quote: Quis fallere possit amantem?
Who can deceive a lover?
author: Virgil, Aeneid (29–19 BC), Book IV, line 296. Variant: "Who could deceive a lover?"

quote: Amor omnibus idem.
Love is lord of all, and is in all the same.
author: Virgil, Georgics (29 BC), III, 244

quote: Love is a minefield. You take a step and get blown to pieces, put yourself back together again and stupidly take another step. I guess that's human nature. It hurts so much to be alone that we'd all rather blow up than be single.
author: Kate Welles (Famke Janssen) in Love & Sex (2000)

quote: An ounce of love is worth a pound of knowledge.
author: John Wesley, The Works of the Rev. John Wesley (1830), p. 393

quote: Dearest comrades, all is over and long gone, But love is not over...
author: Walt Whitman in Leaves of Grass, SONGS OF PARTING, Ashes of Soldiers

quote: Breathe "God," in any tongue — it means the same;
LOVE ABSOLUTE: Think, feel, absorb the thought;
Shut out all else; until a subtle flame
(A spark from God's creative centre caught)
Shall permeate your being, and shall glow,
Increasing in its splendour, till, YOU KNOW.
author: Ella Wheeler Wilcox, New Thought Pastels (1913), Knowledge

quote: When one is in love, one always begins by deceiving one's self, and one always ends by deceiving others. That is what the world calls a romance.
author: Oscar Wilde, The Picture of Dorian Gray, ch. 4

quote: How can anyone be against love?
author: Malcolm X, By any means necessary: speeches, interviews, and a letter (1970)

quote: Much ado there was, God wot;
He woold love, and she woold not,
She sayd, "Never man was trewe;"
He sayes, "None was false to you."
author: Nicholas Breton, Phillida and Corydon

quote: Odi et amo. Quare id faciam, fortasse requiris.
Nescio: sed fieri sentio, et excrucior.
author: Catullus, Carmina, LXXXV

quote: Better to love amiss than nothing to have loved.
author: George Crabbe, The Struggles of Conscience, Tale 14

quote: Poor love is lost in men's capacious minds,
In ours, it fills up all the room it finds.
author: John Crowne, Thyestes

quote: Venus, thy eternal sway
All the race of men obey.
author: Euripides, Iphigenia in Aulis

quote: Und Lust und Liebe sind die Fittige zu grossen Thaten.
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Iphigenia auf Tauris, II. 1. 107

quote: Quand on n'a pas ce que l'on aime, il faut aimer ce que l'on a.
author: Jean-François Marmontel, quoted by Moore in Irish Melodies, The Irish Peasant to His Mistress, Note

quote: Great men,
Till they have gained their ends, are giants in
Their promises, but, those obtained, weak pigmies
In their performance. And it is a maxim
Allowed among them, so they may deceive,
They may swear anything; for the queen of love,
As they hold constantly, does never punish,
But smile, at lovers' perjuries.
author: Philip Massinger, Great Duke of Florence, Act II, scene 3

quote: L'amour est souvent un fruit de mariage.
author: Molière, Sganarelle, I. 1

quote: Is it, in Heav'n, a crime to love too well?
To bear too tender or too firm a heart,
To act a lover's or a Roman's part?
Is there no bright reversion in the sky
For those who greatly think, or bravely die?
author: Alexander Pope, Elegy on an Unfortunate Lady

quote: Scilicent insano nemo in amore videt.
author: Sextus Propertius, Elegiæ, II. 14. 18

quote: Die Liebe vermindert die weibliche
Feinheit und verstärkt die männliche.
author: Jean Paul Richter, Titan, Zykel 34

quote: Ah, to that far distant strand
Bridge there was not to convey,
Not a bark was near at hand,
Yet true love soon found the way.
author: Friedrich Schiller, Hero and Leander. Bowring's translation

quote: Her blue eyes sought the west afar,
For lovers love the western star.
author: Walter Scott, The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), Canto III, Stanza 24

quote: Where we really love, we often dread more than we desire the solemn moment that exchanges hope for certainty.
author: Anne Louise Germaine de Staël, Corinne (1807), Book VIII, Chapter IV

quote: L'amour est l'histoire de la vie des femmes; c'est un épisode dans celle des hommes.
author: Anne Louise Germaine de Staël, De l'influence des passions, Works, III, p. 135. (Ed. 1820)

quote: Sweetheart, when you walk my way,
Be it dark or be it day;
Dreary winter, fairy May,
I shall know and greet you.
For each day of grief or grace
Brings you nearer my embrace;
Love hath fashioned your dear face,
I shall know you when I meet you.
author: Frank L. Stanton, Greeting

quote: Love is hurt with jar and fret;
Love is made a vague regret.
author: Alfred Tennyson, The Miller's Daughter, Stanza 28

quote: What we can do for another is the test of powers; what we can suffer for is the test of love.
author: Attributed to  Brooke Westcott, in Mixer and Server (1929) by the Hotel and Restaurant Employee's International Alliance and Bartenders' International League of America

quote: O, rank is good, and gold is fair,
And high and low mate ill;
But love has never known a law
Beyond its own sweet will!
author: John Greenleaf Whittier, Amy Wentworth, Stanza 18

quote: Love's a different sort of thing, hot enough to make you flow into something, interflow, cool and anneal and be a weld stronger than what you started with.
author: Theodore Sturgeon, More Than Human (1953)

quote: What paralyzes life is lack of faith and lack of audacity. The difficulty lies not in solving problems but expressing them. And so we cannot avoid this conclusion: it is biologically evident that to gain control of passion and so make it serve spirit must be a condition of progress. Sooner or later, then, the world will brush aside our incredulity and take this step : because whatever is the more true comes out into the open, and whatever is better is ultimately realized. The day will come when, after harnessing the ether, the winds, the tides, gravitation, we shall harness for God the energies of love. And, on that day, for the second time in the history of the world, man will have discovered fire.

Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, "The Evolution of Chastity" (February 1934), as translated in Toward the Future (1975) edited by René Hague, who also suggests "space" as an alternate translation of "the ether."
Variants:

"One day after mastering the winds, the waves, the tides and gravity" — after all the scientific and technological achievements — "we shall harness for God the energies of love. And then, for the second time in the history of the world, man will have discovered fire."

As quoted by R. Sargent Shriver, Jr. in his speech accepting the nomination as the Democratic candidate for vice president, in Washington, D. C. (8 August 1972); this has sometimes been published as if Shriver's interjection "after all the scientific and technological achievements" were part of the original statement, as in The New York Times (9 August 1972), p. 18
What paralyzes life is lack of faith and lack of audacity. The difficulty lies not in solving problems but identifying them.
As translated in The Ignatian Tradition (2009) edited by Kevin F. Burke, Eileen Burke-Sullivan and Phyllis Zagano, p. 86

Love is the only force which can make things one without destroying them. … Some day, after mastering the winds, the waves, the tides and gravity, we shall harness for God the energies of love, and then, for the second time in the history of the world, man will have discovered fire.
As quoted in Seed Sown : Theme and Reflections on the Sunday Lectionary Reading (1996) by Jay Cormier, p. 33

The day will come when, after harnessing space, the winds, the tides, gravitation, we shall harness for God the energies of love. And, on that day, for the second time in the history of the world, humanity will have discovered fire.
As quoted in Fire of Love : Encountering the Holy Spirit (2006) by Donald Goergen, p. 92

The day will come when, after harnessing space, the winds, the tides, gravitation, we shall harness for God the energies of love. And, on that day, for the second time in the history of the world, man will have discovered fire.
author: As quoted in Read for the Cure (2007) by Eileen Fanning, p. v

quote: Sweet is true love though given in vain, in vain;
And sweet is death who puts an end to pain:
I know not which is sweeter, no, not I. Love, art thou sweet? then bitter death must be:
Love, thou art bitter; sweet is death to me.
O Love, if death be sweeter, let me die.
I fain would follow love, if that could be;
I needs must follow death, who calls for me;
Call and I follow, I follow! let me die.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Idylls of the King (1859-1865), Lancelot and Elaine, Line 1000

quote: Love always brings difficulties, that is true, but the good side of it is that it gives energy.
author: Vincent van Gogh, Letter to Theo van Gogh from Nuenen, (c. 9 March 1884)

quote: Omnia vincit Amor; et nos cedamus Amori.
Love conquers all and we must yield to Love.
Virgil, Eclogues (37 BC), Book X, line 69.
author: Variant translation: "Love conquers all; let us, too, yield to love."

quote: A purpose of human life, no matter who is controlling it, is to love whoever is around to be loved.
author: Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. in The Sirens of Titan (1959)
le mystère de l'amour est plus grand que le mystère de la mort.

quote: Living might mean taking chances, but they're worth taking.
Loving might be a mistake, but it's worth making.
author: Lee Ann Womack, I Hope You Dance (2000)

quote: True beauty dwells in deep retreats,
Whose veil is unremoved
Till heart with heart in concord beats,
And the lover is beloved.
author: William Wordsworth, To ____ . (Let other Bards of Angels sing), st. 3 (1824)

quote: I think, am sure, a brother's love exceeds
All the world's loves in its unworldliness.
author: Robert Browning, Blot on the 'Scutcheon, Act II, scene 1

quote: To see her is to love her,
And love but her forever;
For nature made her what she is,
And never made anither!
author: Robert Burns, Bonny Lesley

quote: Mulier cupido quod dicit amanti,
In vento et rapida scribere oportet aqua.
author: Catullus, Carmina, LXX. 3

quote: I have heard of reasons manifold
Why love must needs be blind,
But this is the best of all I hold—
His eyes are in his mind.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge, To a Lady, Stanza 2

quote: Mighty Love's artillery.
author: Richard Crashaw, Wounds of the Lord Jesus, line 2

quote: Love, then, hath every bliss in store;
'Tis friendship, and 'tis something more.
Each other every wish they give;
Not to know love is not to live.
author: John Gay, Plutus, Cupid and Time, line 135

quote: Love understands love; it needs no talk.
author: Francis Ridley Havergal, Royal Commandments, Loving Allegiance

quote: Open your heart and take us in,
Love—love and me.
author: William Ernest Henley, Rhymes and Rhythms, V

quote: Love is and was my Lord and King,
And in his presence I attend
To hear the tidings of my friend,
Which every hour his couriers bring.
CXXVI
author: Alfred Tennyson, In Memoriam A.H.H. (1849), Parts I-CXXXI, CXXVI

quote: Bid me to live, and I will live
Thy Protestant to be:
Or bid me love, and I will give
A loving heart to thee,
A heart as soft, a heart as kind,
A heart as sound and free
As in the whole world thou canst find,
That heart I'll give to thee.
author: Robert Herrick, To Anthea, who may command him anything, No. 268

quote: When we do not love, we sleep, we are children of the dust — but love, and you are a god, you are pure, as on the first day of creation.
author: Leo Tolstoy in War and Peace (1865-1869)

quote: O, love, love, love!
Love is like a dizziness;
It winna let a poor body
Gang about his biziness!
author: Hogg, Love is like a Dizziness, line 9

quote: Love,—the shining goal
Of every human soul.
author: Blanche Shoemaker Wagstaff, Eris: A Dramatic Allegory (New York: Moffat, Yard and Company, 1914), p. 19

quote: From henceforth thou shalt learn that there is love
To long for, pureness to desire, a mount
Of consecration it were good to scale.
author: Jean Ingelow, A Parson's Letter to a Young Poet, Part II, line 55

quote: Life is a game and true love is a trophy.
author: Rufus Wainwright, "Poses"

quote: When late I attempted your pity to move,
Why seemed you so deaf to my prayers?
Perhaps it was right to dissemble your love
But—why did you kick me downstairs?
author: J. P. Kemble, Panel, Act I, scene 1. Quoted from Asylum for Fugitive Pieces, Volume I, p. 15. (1785) where it appeared anonymously. Kemble is credited with its authorship. The Panel is adapted from Bickerstaff's 'Tis Well 'Tis No Worse, but these lines are not therein. It may also be found in Annual Register. Appendix. (1783) P. 201

quote: Consent in virtue knit your hearts so fast,
That still the knot, in spite of death, does last;
For as your tears, and sorrow-wounded soul,
Prove well that on your part this bond is whole,
So all we know of what they do above,
Is that they happy are, and that they love.
Let dark oblivion, and the hollow grave,
Content themselves our frailer thoughts to have;
Well-chosen love is never taught to die,
But with our nobler part invades the sky.
author: Edmund Waller, Poetical Works of Edmund Waller and Sir John Denham (1857)

quote: By the old Moulmein Pagoda, lookin' eastward to the sea,
There's a Burma girl a-settin', and I know she thinks o' me;
For the wind is in the palm-trees, and the temple-bells they say:
"Come you back, you British soldier; come you back to Mandalay!"
author: Rudyard Kipling, Mandalay

quote: Love is to die, love is to not die,
Love is to dance, love is to dance.
Love is to die,
Why don't you not die?
Why don't you dance?
Why don't you dance and dance?
author: Warpaint, Love Is To Die, Warpaint (2014)

quote: Do you know you have asked for the costliest thing
Ever made by the Hand above—
A woman's heart, and a woman's life,
And a woman's wonderful love?
author: Mary T. Lathrop, A Woman's Answer to a Man's Question. Erroneously credited to Mrs. Browning

quote: Love is not consolation, it is light.
author: Simone Weil, as quoted in Simone Weil (1954) by Eric Walter Frederick Tomlin, p. 47

quote: I find a rapture linked with each despair,
Well worth the price of anguish. I detect
More good than evil in humanity.
Love lights more fires than hate extinguishes,
And men grow better as the world grows old.
author: Ella Wheeler Wilcox, Poems of Pleasure (1900), Optimism

quote: Et c'est dans la première flamme
Qu'est tout le nectar du baiser.
author: Lebrun, Mes Souvenirs, ou les Deux Rives de la Seine

quote: Love me little, love me long.
author: Christopher Marlowe, The Jew of Malta (c. 1592), Act IV, scene 6

quote: Keep love in your heart. A life without it is like a sunless garden when the flowers are dead. The consciousness of loving and being loved brings warmth and richness to life that nothing else can bring.
author: Oscar Wilde as quoted by Alvin Redman in The Epigrams of Oscar Wilde (1952)

quote: I love him not, but show no reason wherefore, but this, I do not love the man.
author: Paraphrase of Martial by Rowland Watkyns, Antipathy

quote: To be in love is to surpass one's self.
author: Oscar Wilde, The Picture of Dorian Gray, ch. 5

quote: Yes, loving is a painful thrill,
And not to love more painful still;
But oh, it is the worst of pain,
To love and not be lov'd again.
author: Thomas Moore, Anacreontic, Ode 29

quote: Romance lives by repetition, and repetition converts an appetite into an art. Besides, each time that one loves is the only time one has ever loved. Difference of object does not alter singleness of passion. It merely intensifies it. We can have in life but one great experience at best, and the secret of life is to reproduce that experience as often as possible.
author: Oscar Wilde, The Picture of Dorian Gray, ch. 17

quote: What thing is love?—for (well I wot) love is a thing.
It is a prick, it is a sting.
It is a pretty, pretty thing;
It is a fire, it is a coal,
Whose flame creeps in at every hole!
author: George Peele, Miscellaneous Poems, The Hunting of Cupid

quote: A politics of conscience is still yet possible. And yes... love will prevail.
author: Marianne Williamson,Twitter (10 Jan 20)

quote: Love is the fulfilling of the law.
author: Romans, XIII. 10

quote: Mein Herz ich will dich fragen,
Was ist denn Liebe, sag?
"Zwei Seelen und ein Gedanke,
Zwei Herzen und ein Schlag."
My heart I fain would ask thee
What then is Love? say on.
"Two souls and one thought only
Two hearts that throb as one."
author: Von Münch Bellinghausen (Friedrich Halm)—Der Sohn der Wildniss, Act II. Translation by W. H. Charlton. (Commended by author). Popular translation. of the play is by Marie Lovell—Ingomar the Barbarian. Two souls with but a single thought, / Two hearts that beat as one

quote: Thy love to me was wonderful, passing the love of women.
author: II Samuel. I. 26

quote: The wisest man the warl' e'er saw,
He dearly loved the lasses, O.
author: Robert Burns, Green Grow the Rashes

quote: When you loved me I gave you the whole sun and stars to play with. I gave you eternity in a single moment, strength of the mountains in one clasp of your arms, the volume of all the seas in one impulse of your soul. A moment only; but was it not enough? Were you not paid then for all the rest of your struggle on earth?… When I opened the gates of paradise, were you blind? Was it nothing to you? When all the stars sang in your ears and all the winds swept you the heart of heaven, were you deaf? were you dull? was I no more to you than a bone to a dog? Was it not enough? We spent eternity together; and you ask me for a little lifetime more. We possessed all the universe together; and you ask me to give you my scanty wages as well. I have given you the greatest of all things; and you ask me to give you little things. I gave you your own soul: you ask me for my body as a plaything. Was it not enough? Was it not enough?
author: Bernard Shaw, Getting Married

quote: Two souls in one, two hearts into one heart.
author: Guillaume de Salluste Du Bartas, Divine Weekes and Workes, First Week, Part I. Sixth day, line 1,057

quote: Love, as is told by the seers of old,
Comes as a butterfly tipped with gold,
Flutters and flies in sunlit skies,
Weaving round hearts that were one time cold.
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, Song

quote: I seek for one as fair and gay,
But find none to remind me,
How blest the hours pass'd away
With the girl I left behind me.
author: The Girl I Left Behind Me (1759)

quote: O Love, O great god Love, what have I done,
That thou shouldst hunger so after my death?
My heart is harmless as my life's first day:
Seek out some false fair woman, and plague her
Till her tears even as my tears fill her bed.
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, The Complaint of Lisa

quote: Cogas amantem irasci, amare si velis.
author: Syrus, Maxims

quote: Love is a lock that linketh noble minds,
Faith is the key that shuts the spring of love.
author: Robert Greene, Alcida. Verses Written under a Carving of Cupid Blowing Bladders in the Air

quote: What a sweet reverence is that when a young man deems his mistress a little more than mortal and almost chides himself for longing to bring her close to his heart.
author: Nathaniel Hawthorne, The Marble Faun (1860), Volume II, Chapter XV

quote: And the King with his golden sceptre,
The Pope with Saint Peter's key,
Can never unlock the one little heart
That is opened only to me.
For I am the Lord of a Realm,
And I am Pope of a See;
Indeed I'm supreme in the kingdom
That is sitting, just now, on my knee.
author: C. H. Webb, The King and the Pope

quote: Love rules without rules.

Translation of Italian saying: Amor regge senza legge; as quoted in Dictionary of Foreign Terms Found in English and American Writings of Yesterday and Today, 2nd Edition (1934) edited by Christopher Orlando Sylvester Mawson
Variant translations:
Love reigns without rules.
author: Love holds no law.

quote: Whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth.
author: Hebrews, XII. 6

quote: Alas! for love, if thou art all,
And nought beyond, O earth.
author: Felicia Hemans, The Graves of a Household

quote: Who love too much, hate in the like extreme.
author: Homer, The Odyssey, Book XV, line 79. Pope's translation

quote: Si sine amore, jocisque
Nil est jucundum, vivas in amore jocisque.
author: Horace, Epistles, I. 6. 65

quote: What's our baggage? Only vows,
Happiness, and all our care,
And the flower that sweetly shows
Nestling lightly in your hair.
author: Victor Hugo, Eviradnus, XI

quote: Love leads to present rapture,—then to pain;
But all through Love in time is healed again.
author: Charles Godfrey Leland, Sweet Marjoram

quote: Love contending with friendship, and self with each generous impulse.
To and fro in his breast his thoughts were heaving and dashing,
As in a foundering ship.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, The Courtship of Miles Standish (1858), Part III, line 7

quote: Hei mihi! quod nullis amor est medicabilis herbis.
author: Ovid, Metamorphoses, I. 523

quote: Qui amat, tamen hercle si esurit, nullum esurit.
author: Plautus, Casina, IV. 2. 16

quote: Raum ist in der kleinsten Hütte
Für ein glücklich liebend Paar.
author: Friedrich Schiller, Der Jüngling am Bache, Stanza 4

quote: Qui blandiendo dulce nutrivit malum,
Sero recusat ferre, quod subiit, jugum.
author: Seneca the Younger, Hippolytus, CXXXIV

quote: Just like Love is yonder rose,
Heavenly fragrance round it throws,
Yet tears its dewy leaves disclose,
And in the midst of briars it blows
Just like Love.
author: Viscount Strangford, Just like Love, Translation of Poems of Camoens

quote: In all I wish, how happy should I be,
Thou grand Deluder, were it not for thee?
So weak thou art that fools thy power despise;
And yet so strong, thou triumph'st o'er the wise.
author: Jonathan Swift, To Love

quote: If love were what the rose is,
And I were like the leaf,
Our lives would grow together
In sad or singing weather.
author: Algernon Charles Swinburne, A Match

quote: When gloaming treads the heels of day
And birds sit cowering on the spray,
Along the flowery hedge I stray,
To meet mine ain dear somebody.
author: Robert Tannahill, Love's Fear

quote: Perjuria ridet amantium Jupiter et ventos irrita ferre jubet.
author: Tibullus, Carmina, III, 6, 49

quote: So long as we love we serve; so long as we are loved by others, I would almost say that we are indispensable; and no man is useless while he has a friend.
author: Robert Louis Stevenson, "Lay Morals" Ch. 4, in Lay Morals and Other Essays (1911)

quote: Yet is there one true line, the pearl of pearls:
Man dreams of Fame while woman wakes to love.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Idylls of the King (1856–1885), chapter Merlin and Vivien

quote: Lady, for indeed
I loved you and I deemed you beautiful,
I cannot brook to see your beauty marred
Through evil spite: and if ye love me not,
I cannot bear to dream you so forsworn:
I had liefer ye were worthy of my love,
Than to be loved again of you — farewell;
And though ye kill my hope, not yet my love,
Vex not yourself: ye will not see me more.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Idylls of the King (1856–1885), chapter Pelleas and Ettarre

quote: My doom is, I love thee still.
Let no man dream but that I love thee still.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Idylls of the King (1859-1865), Guinevere

quote: Some people have been trying for centuries to love their neighbor as themselves. But they have been finding it difficult because loving your neighbor as yourself really means, first of all, you need to be in touch with yourself, the self that you are beyond the form. And then you can love your neighbor as yourself because you recognize your oneness with your neighbor.
author: Eckhart Tolle quoted in  The Wisdom of Sundays: Life-Changing Insights from Super Soul Conversations, by Oprah Winfrey,  (17 October 2017)

quote: There's no beginning
There be no end
Cause on my love
You can depend
author: The Troggs, Love Is All Around (1967)

quote: It is sad not to be loved, but it is much sadder not to be able to love.
author: Miguel de Unamuno, To a Young Writer

quote: Consciousness (conscientia) is participated knowledge, is co-feeling, and co-feeling is com-passion. Love personalizes all that it loves. Only by personalizing it can we fall in love with an idea. And when love is so great and so vital, so strong and so overflowing, that it loves everything, then it personalizes everything and discovers that the total All, that the Universe, is also a person possessing a Consciousness, a Consciousness which in its turn suffers, pities, and loves, and therefore is consciousness. And this Consciousness of the Universe, which a love, personalizing all that it loves, discovers, is what we call God.
author: Miguel de Unamuno, The Tragic Sense of Life (1913), Del Sentimiento Trágico de la Vida as translated by J. E. Crawford Flitch (1921), VII: Love, Suffering, Pity

quote: Only love can break your heart.
author: Neil Young, Only love can break your heart

quote: Che amar chi t'odia, ell'è impossibil cosa.
author: Vittorio Alfieri, Polinice, II. 4

quote: How many times do I love, again?
Tell me how many beads there are
In a silver chain
Of evening rain
Unravelled from the trembling main
And threading the eye of a yellow star:—
So many times do I love again.
author: Thomas Lovell Beddoes, How Many Times

quote: Love has no thought of self!
Love buys not with the ruthless usurer's gold
The loathsome prostitution of a hand
Without a heart! Love sacrifices all things
To bless the thing it loves!
author: Edward Bulwer-Lytton, The Lady of Lyons, Act V, scene 2, line 23

quote: He that loves a rosy cheek,
Or a coral lip admires,
Or from star-like eyes doth seek
Fuel to maintain his fires,
As Old Time makes these decay,
So his flames must waste away.
author: Thomas Carew, Disdain Returned

quote: Then fly betimes, for only they
Conquer love, that run away.
author: Thomas Carew, Song, Conquest by Flight

quote: Let Time and Chance combine, combine!
Let Time and Chance combine!
The fairest love from heaven above,
That love of yours was mine,
My Dear!
That love of yours was mine.
author: Thomas Carlyle, Adieu

quote: And I, what is my crime I cannot tell,
Vnless it be a crime to haue lou'd too well.
author: Richard Crashaw, Alexias

quote: In einem Augenblick gewährt die Liebe
Was Mühe kaum in langer Zeit erreicht.
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Torquato Tasso, II. 3. 76

quote: Whoe'er thou art, thy Lord and master see,
Thou wast my Slave, thou art, or thou shalt be.
author: George Granville, 1st Baron Lansdowne, Inscription for a Figure representing the God of Love. See Genuine Works. (1732) I. 129. Version of a Greek couplet from the Greek Anthology

quote: Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends.
author: John, XV. 13

quote: Love in a hut, with water and a crust,
Is—Love, forgive us!—cinders, ashes, dust.
author: John Keats, Lamia, Part II

quote: Love begins with love.
author: Jean de La Bruyère, The Characters and Manners of the Present Age, Chapter IV

quote: I loved you ere I knew you; know you now,
And having known you, love you better still.
author: Owen Meredith (Lord Lytton), Vanini

quote: No, the heart that has truly loved never forgets,
But as truly loves on to the close,
As the sunflower turns on her god, when he sets,
The same look which she turn'd when he rose.
author: Thomas Moore, Believe Me, If All Those Endearing Young Charms, Stanza 2

quote: Qui finem quæris amoris,
(Cedit amor rebus) res age; tutus eris.
author: Ovid, Remedia Amoris, CXLIII

quote: Your love in a cottage is hungry,
Your vine is a nest for flies—
Your milkmaid shocks the Graces,
And simplicity talks of pies!
You lie down to your shady slumber
And wake with a bug in your ear,
And your damsel that walks in the morning
Is shod like a mountaineer.
author: Nathaniel Parker Willis, Low in a Cottage, Stanza 3

quote: He loves not well whose love is bold!
I would not have thee come too nigh.
The sun's gold would not seem pure gold
Unless the sun were in the sky:
To take him thence and chain him near
Would make his beauty disappear.
author: William Winter, Love's Queen

quote: There are a great deal of a great many kinds of love.
author: Lytton Strachey to Dora Carrington, 23.3.1917

quote: I remember wondering smokily whether anyone ever loves a person. People seem to love dreams instead, and for the lucky ones, the person is close to the dream. But it’s a dream all the same, a sticky dream. You unload the person, and the dream stays with you.
author: Theodore Sturgeon, The Martian and the Moron (Originally published in the March 1949 issue of Weird Tales).

quote: Love can make you hostage, want to do it again?
author: Sugar Ray, "Fly" (1997)

quote: But if anyone loves God, this one is known by him.
author: Paul of Tarsus, 1 Corinthians 8:3

quote: A universal love is not only psychologically possible; it is the only complete and final way in which we are able to love.
author: Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, The Phenomenon of Man (1955)

quote: The soul of love is the invincible difference of lovers, while its subtle matter is the identity of their desires.
author: Paul Valéry, "Dance and the Soul" (1921), in Dialogues (Bollingen Series XLV 4/ Princeton University Press, 1989), translated by William McCausland Stewart, p. 47

quote: It's the Roman god, Janus. My mother gave it to me when I was little. She wanted to teach me that people have two sides. A good side, a bad side, a past, a future. And that we must embrace both in someone we love.
author: Elise Clifton-Ward (played by Angelina Jolie) in The Tourist

quote: Just let your love flow like a mountain stream
And let your love grow with the smallest of dreams
And let your love show and you'll know what I mean
It's the season
Let your love fly like a bird on a wing
And let your love bind you to all livin' things
And let your love shine and you'll know what I mean
That's the reason.
author: Larry E. Williams, in Let Your Love Flow (1976)

quote: Many who are careful with their money no sooner fall in love than they begin to waste it: and when they have spent it all, they no longer shrink from making more by methods which they formerly avoided because they thought them disgraceful.
author: Xenophon, Memorabilia, 1.2.22

quote: You know when I said I knew little about love? That wasn't true. I know a lot about love. I've seen it, seen centuries and centuries of it, and it was the only thing that made watching your world bearable. All those wars. Pain, lies, hate... Made me want to turn away and never look down again. But to see the way that mankind loves... I mean, you could search to the furthest reaches of the universe and never find anything more beautiful. So, yes, I know that love is unconditional. But I also know it can be unpredictable, unexpected, uncontrollable, unbearable and strangely easy to mistake for loathing, and... What I'm trying to say, Tristan, is... I think I love you. My heart... It feels like my chest can barely contain it. Like it doesn't belong to me any more. It belongs to you. And if you wanted it, I'd wish for nothing in exchange — no gifts, no goods, no demonstrations of devotion. Nothing but knowing you loved me, too. Just your heart, in exchange for mine.
author: "Yvaine" in Stardust (2007 film), based on Stardust (1998), by Neil Gaiman

quote: Truth, like a woman, must be wooed and won - and this is only through the purity of mind and the heart’s deep love.
author: David Zindell, The Wild (1995), p. 388

quote: Ma vie a son secret, mon âme a son mystére:
Un amour éternel en un moment concu.
La mal est sans remède, aussi j'ai dû le taire,
Et elle qui l'a fait n'en a jamais rien su.
author: Félix Arvers, Sonnet. Translation by Joseph Knight. In The Athenæum, Jan. 13, 1906. Arvers in Mes Heures Perdues, says that the sonnet was "mite de l'italien"

quote: In your arms was still delight,
Quiet as a street at night;
And thoughts of you, I do remember,
Were green leaves in a darkened chamber,
Were dark clouds in a moonless sky.
author: Rupert Brooke, Retrospect

quote: Heaven's great artillery.
author: Richard Crashaw, Flaming Heart, line 56

quote: Greensleeves was all my joy,
Greensleeves was my delight,
Greensleeves was my heart of gold,
And who but Lady Greensleeves?
author: A new Courtly Sonnet of the Lady Greensleeves, to the new tune of "Greensleeves", from "A Handful of Pleasant Deities" (1584)

quote: Soft is the breath of a maiden's Yes:
Not the light gossamer stirs with less;
But never a cable that holds so fast
Through all the battles of wave and blast.
author: Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr., Songs of Many Seasons, Dorothy, II, Stanza 7

quote: Let those love now who never lov'd before,
Let those who always loved now love the more.
author: Thomas Parnell—Translation of the Pervigilium Veneris. Ancient poem. Author unknown. Ascribed to Catullus. See also Burton—Anatomy of Melancholy, Part III, Section II. Memb. 5. 5

quote: Auro contra cedo modestum amatorem.
author: Plautus, Curculio, I. 3. 45

quote: If all the world and love were young,
And truth in every shepherd's tongue,
These pretty pleasures might me move
To live with thee, and be thy love.
author: Sir Walter Raleigh, The Nymph's Reply to the Passionate Shepherd

quote: Oh! she was good as she was fair.
None—none on earth above her!
As pure in thought as angels are,
To know her was to love her.
author: Samuel Rogers, Jacqueline, Part I, line 68

quote: Trust thou thy Love: if she be proud, is she not sweet?
Trust thou thy love: if she be mute, is she not pure?
Lay thou thy soul full in her hands, low at her feet—
Fail, Sun and Breath!—yet, for thy peace, she shall endure.
author: John Ruskin, Trust Thou Thy Love

quote: Love's not Time's fool, though rosy lips and cheeks
Within his bending sickle's compass come;
Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,
But bears it out even to the edge of doom.
If this be error and upon me prov'd,
I never writ, nor no man ever lov'd.
author: William Shakespeare, Sonnet CXVI

quote: And my heart springs up anew,
Bright and confident and true,
And the old love comes to meet me, in the dawning and the dew.
author: Robert Louis Stevenson, poem written 1876

quote: I loved you, and my love had no return,
And therefore my true love has been my death.
author: Alfred Tennyson, Lancelot and Elaine, line 1,298
